newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish shares extend gains, seen up on Friday.
newsitem.headline: Polish shares extend gains, seen up on Friday.

text.p: Polish shares rose for the second straight session and analysts said the dominant buying after price-fixing signalled prices were attractive enough for the bourse to extend gains on Friday.
They said the market, which has risen 8.5 percent since December 10, might be benefiting from the expectation that investment funds would buy more at the start of the year.

"That's a possibility, but we'll have to see how turnovers go, because they're low now, possibly because some investors might have taken a vacation during the short week," said Ryszard Wojnowski, an analyst at Bank Gdanski brokerage.
The main market's all-share WIG index rose 0.6 percent to 14,423.8 and turnover fell 20.7 percent to 68.1 million zlotys on both markets.
Analysts said the main market could test its October 9, 30-month high at 15,078.7 points later in the quarter.
They said investors may have already priced in the central bank's comments it might raise interest rates as early as mid-January to curb fast credit growth.
"Also rates might only increase by about one percent to scare investors a little, because any more might be too dear," said Roman Sosnowski, an analyst at Bank Staropolski brokerage.
Analysts said top gainer Novita surged 9.5 percent after it sold a stake in a subsidiary.
They said Espebepe surged 9.3 percent on speculative demand, as the firm still had financial problems.
They said Sokolow, up 7.5 percent in active trade, may have been helped by its Thursday statement it sought a strategic investor.
NFI units rose 0.7 percent to 143.5 zlotys but fell the same amount to 145 zlotys in 9.1-million-zloty continuous trade. -- Steven Silber +48 22 653 9700
